Name: CosMx RNA Data Types Viz Test
Appendix:
For more information on NanoString CosMx technology visit [**our website**](https://nanostring.com/products/cosmx-spatial-molecular-imager/single-cell-imaging-overview/).

Details of the performance of GeoMx Whole Transcriptome Atlas (WTA) have been [**published**](https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.09.29.462442).

Minerva is an open-source software package that was developed by Laboratory of Systems Pharmacology at Harvard University and is available [**here**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki). We would like to thank Jeremy Muhlich and John Thomas Hoffer for assistance in enabling Minerva features to support the Spatial Organ Atlas.

Sources:
* Rashid R, Chen YA, Hoffer J, et al. Narrative online guides for the interpretation of digital-pathology images and tissue-atlas data. Nat Biomed Eng. Published online November 8, 2021:1-12. [doi:10.1038/s41551-021-00789-8](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41551-021-00789-8)
* Hoffer J, Rashid R, Muhlich JL, et al. Minerva: a light-weight, narrative image browser for multiplexed tissue images. Journal of Open Source Software. 2020;5(54):2579. [doi:10.21105/joss.02579](https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02579)

Stories.Description:
Welcome to this CosMx test Minerva Story. The objectives of this Story are to test the following items:
* Cell segmentation visualization
* Multiple channels in CosMx OME-TIFF
* RNA density visualization
It is only one FOV.

Waypoints.Name: Waypoint 1
Waypoints.Description:
This is the first waypoint. Check out segmentation!
* Channel 1 = 488 nm, CD298/B2M
* Channel 2 = 532 nm, PanCK
* Channel 3 = 594 nm, Glucagon
* Channel 4 = 647 nm, Insulin
* Channel 5 = UV, DAPI

Waypoints.Name: Waypoint 2
Waypoints.Description: Check out cell typing! The final Story will not have all cells as one mask.

Waypoints.Name: Waypoint 3
Waypoints.Description:
RNA spots for one target are shown here. The three levels of masks shown below indicate RNA spot density. 'Level3' is the greatest spot density, that is, a pixel with the largest number of RNA spots underneath it. Note that the **n** levels can be condensed into one mask, e.g., the mouse dev gene expression masks. That was not done here in the interest of time. It's a post-Minerva Author step done with a custom Python script to collapse different masks together.
The concern here was that having each pixel being the same color, regardless of the number of RNA spots at that location, would make a blob. We wanted to test out a heatmap, similar to this image:
 ![image](img/RNA_spot_density_heatmap.png) This is still in development.

Note we can distinguish fiducials where RNA spots are excluded. See the arrow on the base image.
